detail.title: Multidimensional Synergistic Management of Acid Mine Drainage: Constructing Closed-Loop Technological Systems Bridging Contamination Control and Resource Circulation
detail.abstract: Acid mine drainage (AMD), as a typical pollutant generated during mining activities, poses significant threats to the ecological environment due to its unique physicochemical properties. This paper systematically reviewed recent research progress in the field of AMD treatment, with a focus on the transition from traditional treatment technologies to integrated resource recovery and comprehensive management models. Guided by the principles of a circular economy, the study constructed a tripartite technical system encompassing “pollution control-resource recovery-ecological restoration”, and provided a detailed analysis of the synergistic mechanisms of key technologies such as physicochemical treatment, bioremediation, and the application of novel functional materials. The article thoroughly examined the principles and effectiveness of advanced technologies like selective adsorption, membrane separation, and bioelectrochemical systems in AMD treatment, while outlining optimization pathways for multi-technology coupling systems. Additionally, it analyzed current challenges in practical applications, including water quality complexity and operational stability, and explored future development directions such as intelligent monitoring and the development of new functional materials. This review aimed to provide theoretical references for the innovation and engineering application of AMD treatment technologies.

title: Policies for Fighting Corruption and Encouraging Sustainable Economic Development in E-8 Countries
affiliations: Ghazi University

detail.title: Policies for Fighting Corruption and Encouraging Sustainable Economic Development in E-8 Countries
detail.abstract: According to study, political conflict afflicted with E-8 countries. But since 2001, the system has shown signs of stability. A country's political instability increases the factors that contribute to systemic corruption. This study examined the effects of per capita income, natural resource exploitation, and political instability (PIS) on industrial advancement. We constructed linear and non-linear ARDL models using data sets from 1985 to 2021. The idea was confirmed when both approaches were applied to the E-8 countries. Based on our research, countries GDP grows stably when it has natural resources, as opposed to the opposite effect of politically stable Syndrome (PIS). On the other hand, corruption raises GDP initially before decreasing it over time. GDP decreases when levels of corruption increase, and GDP grows in the opposite direction from the symmetric relationship that long-term statistics reveal among the two categories. The correlation between these findings and the proposed preparations indicates the need for a more open and honest national framework lacking of partiality. In addition to fostering economic growth, this will enable the countries to challenge its most urgent problems, which include political instability, corruption, and resource waste.

title: Leveraging the Microgeography of Neighborhoods to Estimate the Causal Effects of Flood Damage: Evidence from Hurricane Harvey
affiliations: University of Southern California

detail.title: Leveraging the Microgeography of Neighborhoods to Estimate the Causal Effects of Flood Damage: Evidence from Hurricane Harvey
detail.abstract: The combination of climate change and economic growth in disaster-prone regions increasingly exposes the population to extreme weather events. The responses and resilience of households are key determinants of the social cost of climate change. By exploiting the microgeography of neighborhoods and exposure to flooding, I estimate the average treatment effects of household-level damage using a fuzzy regression discontinuity design. I leverage the relationship between a home’s elevation and flooding during Hurricane Harvey, exploiting a discontinuous increase in damage from $0 to approximately $48,000 once water reaches the first floor of the structure. I provide novel evidence that disaster damage increases homeowner relocation while delaying property sales. The impacts on residential mobility attenuate over time, but I document a persistent divergence in the location and type of housing selected by damage-induced movers. My results indicate that flood damage makes people more likely to move shorter distances, and damage-induced movers are more likely to transition out of homeownership. Despite the combined shock to shelter and wealth, I find that flooded households are more likely to sort into higher-income census tracts. By evaluating the impact of direct household damage instead of neighborhood-level measures, this study provides new insights into how disaster damage affects residential choices.

title: Connecting Markets, Changing Diets: Evidence from Indonesian Maritime Logistic Subsidies
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Universitas Indonesia and Universitas Indonesia

detail.title: Connecting Markets, Changing Diets: Evidence from Indonesian Maritime Logistic Subsidies
detail.abstract: Better market access is among the key drivers of adequate dietary patterns, particularly in developing countries. Nevertheless, empirical evidence of how market access improvement affects dietary outcomes remains scant. In this study, we estimate the effect of improvement in transport-led market access on dietary patterns using Indonesia as a case study. The country launched a maritime logistics subsidy, the Sea-Toll Program (STP), for specific essential commodities, including food, connecting hub ports to geographically more isolated and economically disadvantaged regions. Using a unique household-level repeated cross-section and a triple differences model, the estimates, though modest in magnitude, suggest that the introduction of STP led to an increase in overall dietary intake, alongside gains in dietary diversity, and balance for households located near STP transit ports, with particularly significant effects on animal-sourced foods and processed foods. We provide suggestive evidence that the changes in staple food affordability partly explain this shift in dietary composition.

title: Choosing and Implementing Optimal Immigration Policies
affiliations: Texas A&M University and Stanford University

detail.title: Choosing and Implementing Optimal Immigration Policies
detail.abstract: We formulate immigration as an assignment problem between a destination country and a home country, factoring in the objectives of migrants, natives, and a social planner. We compare government rationing with market-based approaches. We calibrate the model to identify an optimal price for each country, which averages $80,935. At current immigration rates, this would generate $67 billion in annual revenue. Selling visas can reduce tension between capital and labor among natives that leads to accepting fewer than the socially optimal number of immigrants. The model predicts that countries with high income inequality will restrict immigration, consistent with evidence.

title: Variational Bayesian Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Urban Infrastructure Investment Decision-Making
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Variational Bayesian Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Urban Infrastructure Investment Decision-Making
detail.abstract: Urban infrastructure planning under uncertainty demands advanced decision-making frameworks that can balance investment risk, policy constraints, and temporal-spatial dynamics. This paper proposes a novel Variational Bayesian Deep Reinforcement Learning (VB-DRL) framework that integrates a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) for latent representation learning, a Bayesian Actor-Critic policy with Lyapunov-constrained Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) optimization, and a Gaussian Process Temporal Difference (GPTD) module for uncertainty-aware reward estimation. The approach is tailored for high-dimensional investment environments where real-time adaptability, resilience, and probabilistic modeling are critical. By embedding Bayesian reasoning within the policy network and updating via Bayesian Gradient Descent (BGD), the framework captures posterior distributions over policy parameters, enabling robust exploration and reduced variance in policy gradients. Experimental results on a synthesized urban grid environment, informed by real-world infrastructure datasets, demonstrate superior performance in long-term return maximization, budget adherence, and investment resilience under stochastic disruptions. The model also provides a tractable measure of epistemic uncertainty, essential for policy interpretability and risk-sensitive decision-making. This work advances urban planning automation by offering a theoretically grounded, data-driven, and uncertainty-aware methodology that can be extended to smart city, energy grid, and transportation investment domains.

title: Lifecycle-Aware Security Evaluation of Programmable Defi Hooks: A Framework for Uniswap V4
affiliations: Kangwon National University and Kangwon National University

detail.title: Lifecycle-Aware Security Evaluation of Programmable Defi Hooks: A Framework for Uniswap V4
detail.abstract: HighlightsLifecycle-Aware Security Evaluation of Programmable DeFi Hooks: A Framework for Uniswap V4The programmable hook architecture introduced in Uniswap V4 enables external logic to be executed at predefined lifecycle events within automated market maker (AMM) protocols, enhancing the customizability. However, this design introduces a novel attack surface that conventional static analysis tools are ill-equipped to handle, particularly due to hooks’ context-dependent behavior and lack of publicly available source code. This paper proposes HookScope, a lifecycle-aware dynamic analysis framework for evaluating the structural security of programmable hooks. HookScope defines five runtime threat types (T1–T5) specific to the Uniswap V4 hook model and employs simulation-based testing to detect their manifestation during live contract execution. Risk scores are computed using a CVSS-inspired model that incorporates threat severity, execution context, and system-level impact. Comparative evaluation demonstrates that HookScope identifies threats overlooked by static tools such as Mythril, highlighting the necessity of lifecycle-aware dynamic analysis for programmable DeFi infrastructure. The proposed framework contributes a reproducible, quantifiable approach to threat detection in decentralized protocols and provides a foundation for future research on secure extensibility in AMM-based systems.

title: Soil Health Investment and Financial Performance of Crop Farms
affiliations: Kansas State University, Kansas State University, Kansas State University - Department of Agricultural Economics, Kansas State University, Kansas State University and Kansas State University

detail.title: Soil Health Investment and Financial Performance of Crop Farms
detail.abstract: Soil health investments (SHI) are widely promoted for their environmental benefits, yet evidence of their relationship with farm profitability is mixed and limited by data availability. This study investigates the relationship between SHI and farm profitability using detailed financial records of Kansas commercial crop farms, combined with data from a survey on practice adoption. We construct and compare three typical classification frameworks for measuring SHI: an agronomic scoring system grounded in regenerative principles, a threshold-based rule classification, and an unsupervised cluster analysis. We then estimate the relationship between profitability and SHI using Ordinary Least Squares. Only a high-ranking agronomic score shows a consistent and statistically significant positive association with profitability. Farms scoring high under this method saw a 5.6 percentage point higher net farm income ratio on average. Expert-informed, context-sensitive approaches to measuring SHI are more predictive of financial performance than purely rule- or data-driven alternatives. Substantial disagreement between classification methods—only 10% of farms were consistently ranked high across all three—underscores the methodological challenge in quantifying SHI intensity. These inconsistencies have implications for research, as well as policy and incentive design, particularly where SHI definitions determine access to subsidies or market benefits.

title: Energy-Efficient Device-to-Device Communication Optimization for Autonomous Mobile Robots Over Industrial Iot Networks
affiliations: Chungbuk National University and Electronics and Telecommunications Research Institute

detail.title: Energy-Efficient Device-to-Device Communication Optimization for Autonomous Mobile Robots Over Industrial Iot Networks
detail.abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) has emerged as a novel paradigm for smart manufacturing that supports reliable and real-time network systems. The application of IIoT-based manufacturing systems handles large amounts of data across various components, including sensors and robots for industrial automation. Although routing protocols for IIoT applications have already supported various connectivity characteristics, there is still a lack of mobility. In this paper, we propose an IIoT-based device-to-device (D2D) network system that supports energy-efficient mobility of autonomous mobile robot (AMR). Moreover, a stochastic game theory is devised to formulate the D2D network system using the game theory-based optimization algorithm (GTA). We apply GTA to maximize the data rate of AMR and derive the Nash equilibrium as a solution of the stochastic game theory by the best response strategy in various simulation environments. The results demonstrate that GTA can enhance performance by maximizing the average data rate, as well as maintaining the average energy consumption.

title: Mobile Internet Connectivity and Household Wealth in the Philippines
affiliations: University of Cambridge - Department of Land Economy, London School of Economics & Political Science (LSE) - Department of Geography and Environment and Asian Development Bank

detail.title: Mobile Internet Connectivity and Household Wealth in the Philippines
detail.abstract: Mobile internet has become a fundamental modern infrastructure. We consider how access influences household wealth in the Philippines using a granular measure of local connectivity based on geocoded cell towers and identify causal impact through a instrument based on proximity to submarine cable landing points. Our results show that mobile internet connectivity increases household wealth, with effects across education levels and most pronounced in urban areas. We investigate mechanisms and demonstrate that improved connectivity stimulates activity in several economic sectors. Mobile internet enhances educational outcomes and promotes female labor force participation, though predominantly in occasional roles.

title: Bayesian Updating-Based Maintenance Strategy Optimization for Corroded Pipeline Systems Combined with a Heuristic Genetic Algorithm
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Southeast University and Southeast University

detail.title: Bayesian Updating-Based Maintenance Strategy Optimization for Corroded Pipeline Systems Combined with a Heuristic Genetic Algorithm
detail.abstract: Pipelines are the primary infrastructure for transporting energy resources, such as oil and natural gas, over long distances. Corrosion poses significant risks to pipeline safety and economic efficiency, making effective in-line inspections and robust maintenance strategies essential. Given the inherent randomness in corrosion progression, the variability in pipeline defects, and the complexity of pipeline system structures, this study develops a novel optimization framework that integrates Bayesian theory with a heuristic genetic algorithm. First, an enhanced Bayesian updating approach is utilized to refine the parameters of corrosion degradation models, thereby reducing uncertainty and improving the prediction accuracy of corrosion progression. Based on the refined corrosion model, a genetic algorithm specifically tailored for pipeline maintenance optimization is proposed, including customized encoding and mutation rules to achieve rapid convergence and effectively avoid local optima. Through iterative application, the developed framework dynamically updates maintenance strategies using real-time in-line inspection data, thus reducing maintenance costs while ensuring pipeline system reliability. Results from applying the proposed method to long-term pipeline management scenarios demonstrate a significant improvement in both the economic efficiency and reliability of energy transportation systems.

title: Towards Low Pesticide Use: Understanding Farmer Values and Goals in Sustainable Crop Protection Decisions
affiliations: Leibniz-Centre for Agricultural Landscape Research (ZALF), Leibniz-Zentrum für Agrarlandschaftsforschung (ZALF), Leibniz-Centre for Agricultural Landscape Research (ZALF) and University of Göttingen

detail.title: Towards Low Pesticide Use: Understanding Farmer Values and Goals in Sustainable Crop Protection Decisions
detail.abstract: CONTEXTDecisions regarding the adoption of sustainable crop protection practices, such as integrated pest management, are strongly shaped by farmers’ goals, values, and motivations. Understanding these underlying factors is essential for designing effective strategies to promote sustainable agricultural practices, particularly in light of the relatively low uptake of such practices.OBJECTIVEThis study examines how farmer goals and values influence decision-making and shape Polish and German potato farmers' preferences for sustainable crop protection.METHODSAn integrated choice and latent variable framework that combines structural equation modeling with a discrete choice experiment was employed to jointly estimate farmer preferences and the underlying motivational constructs.RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS Findings reveal a nuanced interplay between socio-economic factors and latent motivations. While organic production is positively associated with social and intrinsic values, it is negatively associated with instrumental motivations in both countries, emphasizing the role of non-economic drivers in sustainable farming choices. Farmers driven by intrinsic values prefer practices that substantially reduce pesticide residues and prefer shorter transition periods, whereas those motivated by instrumental values exhibit resistance to such changes due to economic concerns. Farmers exhibiting social motivations favor integrated pest management practices with demonstrable environmental benefits and emphasize the role of advisory support in their decision-making. Further, analysis reveals both convergence and divergence in information-seeking behavior across farmer classes, reflecting shared use of information sources despite differing motivations and how underlying goals shape both the choice and use of information sources. SIGNIFICANCEThese insights underscore the importance of aligning policy tools with diverse farmers' goals and values. Tailoring strategies to accommodate these differences can foster more inclusive, targeted, and effective national efforts to scale up the adoption of sustainable crop protection practices.

title: May Tax Evasion Help Control Public Debt?
affiliations: University of Mannheim, University of Brescia - Department of Economics and Management and University of Brescia

detail.title: May Tax Evasion Help Control Public Debt?
detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of tax evasion on public debt in a dynamic general equilibrium model with incomplete financial markets. In our model, utility-maximising entrepreneurs optimally choose how much to invest in safe government bonds and risky capital production, as well as which percentage of their income to evade. If evasion is audited, a fine must be paid. The government funds non-productive spending through income taxes and debt. Evasion enables entrepreneurs to accumulate more capital, thereby reducing their need to save for unexpected events. In equilibrium, fewer savings mean fewer investments. This lowers economic growth and increases the cost of borrowing for the government, ultimately raising the debt-to-GDP ratio. Nevertheless, when we compare a reduction in the tax burden achieved through a higher tolerance for tax evasion with a reduction in the legal tax, we show that the first strategy leads to a smaller increase in the debt-to-GDP ratio. This is because, unlike tax evasion, legal tax cuts directly increase the return on capital investments, thereby raising the government's borrowing costs in equilibrium.

title: Autonomous Dominant Resource Fairness for Blockchain Ecosystems
affiliations: Independent Researcher

detail.title: Autonomous Dominant Resource Fairness for Blockchain Ecosystems
detail.abstract: HighlightsPrecomputed Dominant Resource Fairness in Blockchain EcosystemsBlockchain systems have been a part of mainstream academic research, and a hot topic at that. It has spread to almost every subfield in the computer science literature, as well as economics and finance. Especially in a world where digital trust is much sought for, blockchains offer a rich variety of desired properties, such as immutability, public auditing, decentralised record keeping, among others. Not only has it been a research topic of its own, the integration of blockchains into other systems has been proposed as solutions in many areas, ranging from grid computing, cloud and fog computing, to internet of things, self driving vehicles , and smart cities. In many cases the primary function attributed to blockchains in these contexts is resource management. Although much attention is paid to this topic, the focus is on single resource allocation scenarios. Even the cases where multiple resource types are to be allocated, are treated as single resource type scenarios, and problems are formulated as allocating standardised bundles consisting of a fixed amount of each of them, such as virtual machines. From a global point of view, this leads to resource waste, since some resources are left idle by the tasks which do not need them, and to which they are allocated along with the resources it needs. The present study addresses the problem of allocating multiple resource types among tasks with heterogeneous resource demands with a smart contract adaptation of Precomputed Dominant Resource Fairness; an algorithm that approximates Dominant Resource Fairness, without loop iterations, which makes it preferable in the blockchain context because of the block gas limit. We present the resulting algorithm, Autonomous Dominant Resource Fairness, along with the empirical data collected from the tests run on the algorithm. The results show that Autonomous Dominant Resource Fairness is a gas-cost efficient algorithm, which can be used to manage hundreds of resource types for unlimited number of users.

title: Protection for Sale Without Aggregation Bias
affiliations: University of Geneva, University of Geneva and University of Geneva

detail.title: Protection for Sale Without Aggregation Bias
detail.abstract: Estimates of Grossman and Helpman's (1994) Protection For Sale (PFS) model yield unrealistically high estimates of the weight governments put on social welfare relative to lobbying contributions. Estimates of the former are often close to 1. We argue this is due to the level of aggregation at which the model is estimated. While protection is determined at the tariff line level, production data are only available at the industry level. Using a new production dataset at the tariff level, our estimates show that the average weight on social welfare in a sample of 146 countries declines by 80 percent.

title: Mobility Responses of Foreign-Born to Native-Biased Labor Supply Shocks: Evidence from Post-Wwii Us
affiliations: Yonsei University

detail.title: Mobility Responses of Foreign-Born to Native-Biased Labor Supply Shocks: Evidence from Post-Wwii Us
detail.abstract: While immigrants may prefer cities with smaller native supply shocks to avoid labor market competition, high-skill biased supply shocks can attract foreign-born individuals if these shocks enhance local productivity and amenities. Using the geographic variation in the return of WWII veterans during the post-WWII period driven by veterans’ prewar communities, I find that immigrants do not systematically avoid cities with larger native supply shocks. Certain immigrant groups, such as women and those in low-skilled jobs, were more likely to relocate to areas with an increased presence of native veterans. These results suggest that the occupational specialization of veterans, productivity gains associated with skill-biased supply shocks, and increased intermarriage between nativeand foreign-born individuals may have offset the potential negative effects of increased competition. The increased wages of less educated workers in the local economies further support this hypothesis.

title: Adaptive Variable-Timescale Optimal Dispatch of Coal Mine Integrated Energy Systems Based on Collaborative Feedback from Day-Ahead and Intra-Day
affiliations: Zhongyuan University of Technology, Jiangnan University, Zhongyuan University of Technology, Qingdao University of Science and Technology and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Adaptive Variable-Timescale Optimal Dispatch of Coal Mine Integrated Energy Systems Based on Collaborative Feedback from Day-Ahead and Intra-Day
detail.abstract: In coal mine integrated energy systems (CMIES), source-load forecast uncertainty usually leads to high dispatch costs, while the differing response time of electrical and thermal subsystems further aggravates the intra-day dispatch efficiency. Therefore, we here propose an adaptive variable-timescale optimal dispatch strategy for CMIES, which is based on collaborative day-ahead and intra-day feedback to enhance dispatch performance. Firstly, considering the source-load forecast uncertainty, the day-ahead interval dispatch model with multi-objective, and an intra-day dual-layer dispatch model with stability requirements are respectively constructed. Secondly, a collaborative dispatch strategy that combines the model predictive control and conventional dispatch methods is designed to solve the intraday dispatch model with interval variables. Then, based on the deviation in dispatch results between the day-ahead and the slowlayer, we present an adaptive switching criterion between the slow layer and fast layer. Finally, the cumulative deviation of dispatch results between the slow layer and the day-ahead within one hour is calculated, and a day-ahead redispatch strategy with the intra-day dispatch results feedback is proposed. The experimental results show that the proposed method can effectively reduce the dispatch cost and improve dispatch reliability.

title: Field Testing and Simulation of Load Shifting for Grid-Interactive Heat Pump Systems Integrated with Thermal Energy Storage
affiliations: Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Government of the United States of America - Oak Ridge National Laboratory

detail.title: Field Testing and Simulation of Load Shifting for Grid-Interactive Heat Pump Systems Integrated with Thermal Energy Storage
detail.abstract: Integrating thermal energy storage (TES) into grid-interactive heat pump (HP) systems offers significant potential to enhance grid resilience and reduce building operating costs through effective load shifting. This study provides a detailed analysis of load shifting strategies and their impacts on cost savings and grid load. The TES unit is integrated with the HP system via a secondary loop, allowing cooling energy to be stored in phase change material (PCM) and heat transfer fluid (HTF) within the TES unit. The stored energy can later be discharged to provide cooling to the building, decoupling cooling generation from demand and enabling flexible operation. A field study is conducted to compare the TES-HP system with the nonTES-HP system, demonstrating the benefits of integrating TES. An evaluation matrix is proposed, including instantaneous performance, load-shifting performance, accumulated performance, unit-value indexes from both building and equipment perspectives, and peak-hour-only indexes, to comprehensively assess and compare the performance of the TES-HP and non-TES-HP systems. A rule-based control strategy, which considers variations in electricity prices and ambient temperature, is implemented to stabilize building thermal comfort, increase TES charging efficiency, and achieve load shifting. To further supplement the field study, simulation models are developed to analyze the impact of TES cooling storage capacity and heat transfer capability (UA, between the HTF and PCM in the TES unit) on load-shifting performance. Field test results indicate that, with the same thermostat setting, the TES-HP system can achieve hourly grid load reductions of 92%, 58%, and 36% during each peak hour, respectively, and a 39% reduction in 24-hour electricity costs compared to the non-TES-HP system. Isolating the effects of different cooling loads, TES-HP can increase cooling capacity per cost (QpC) by 6.6 times during the first peak hour and by 27% over the entire 24-hour field study period. Simulation results indicate that doubling the storage capacity of TES can reduce hourly cost and power consumption by up to 84.8% during peak hours and reduce 24-hour electricity costs by 38% compared with the original TES unit design. Increasing UA by 10 times can lead to a more than 25% reduction in 24-hour electricity costs, owing to improved system efficiency. In summary, field experiments and simulation studies demonstrate the strong potential of TES-HP systems to enhance energy flexibility and cost efficiency in grid-interactive buildings, making them a promising solution for energy management.

title: Machine Learning Approaches for Groundwater Temperature Prediction: Impacts of Hydro-Climatic Variability, Feature Engineering, and Model Complexity
affiliations: Montanuniversität Leoben, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Montanuniversität Leoben, Montanuniversität Leoben, GeoSphere Austria and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Machine Learning Approaches for Groundwater Temperature Prediction: Impacts of Hydro-Climatic Variability, Feature Engineering, and Model Complexity
detail.abstract: Abstract Accurate groundwater temperature (GWT) prediction is essential for effective water management, yet the potential of machine learning (ML) remains underexplored. This study evaluates the performance of various ML models, ranging from linear and lasso regression to advanced approaches such as support vector regression, random forests, and a deep learning model (LSTM), for GWT prediction across six sites in Austria, each representing distinct hydroclimatic regimes. Three feature sets were analyzed: (i) time parameters only, (ii) climate parameters only, and (iii) integrated time and climate parameters. A generalized additive model using only time features served as the baseline, while LSTM incorporated sequential time and climate features to predict GWT and identify characteristic time lags of climate variables. The results reveal that regular seasonal variations and long-term trends provide robust diagnostics for selecting optimal prediction strategies. Simpler models perform well in highly regular regimes, whereas complex ML models are necessary for irregular GWT patterns. Integrating time and climate features significantly outperforms climate-only models, achieving up to an 81% increase in R² and a 52% error reduction. Stepwise backward selection (SBS) and principal component analysis (PCA) yield comparable performance, but SBS preserves physical interpretability, identifying monthly radiation and air temperature as key predictors. These findings highlight the importance of site-specific strategies for GWT prediction, combining hydro-climatic diagnostics with tailored ML models to account for local seasonal and trend behaviors. This study establishes a foundation for accurate GWT predictions across diverse locations, supporting improved groundwater management in the face of climate variability.

title: An Exact Approach for the Train Single-Routing Selection Problem
affiliations: Sapienza University of Rome, Sapienza University of Rome, ESSEC Business School, affiliation not provided to SSRN, French Institute of Science and Technology for Transport, Development and Networks (IFSTTAR) and Universidad Politecnica de Madrid

detail.title: An Exact Approach for the Train Single-Routing Selection Problem
detail.abstract: Given a set of train routes with route costs and a set of compatible route pairs with pairing costs, the Train Single-Routing Selection Problem (TSRSP) seeks to assign one route to each train, minimizing the total cost while ensuring pairwise compatibility among the selected routes. This problem is of significant practical relevance in rail traffic management and it is a special case of the Train Routing Selection Problem. We introduce a Binary Quadratic Programming formulation for the TSRSP and apply a linearization technique from the literature that requires a linear number of additional variables and constraints. This yields a novel and effective Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) formulation for the TSRSP. By exploiting the structure of the problem, we further propose a method to strengthen the Linear Programming (LP) relaxation of the MILP formulation, substantially improving its computational performance. The resulting formulation is the first to efficiently solve real-world TSRSP instances to optimality within short computational times—instances that, until now, have only been addressed using heuristic approaches in the literature. Extensive computational results show that our MILP model consistently outperforms existing formulations, both in terms of computational time and the number of instances solved to optimality, primarily due to the strength of its LP relaxation.

title: Network Deployment and Capacity Configuration of Battery Swapping Stations for Heavy-Duty Electric Tractor Fleets in Field Work
affiliations: Taizhou University, China Agricultural University, China Agricultural University, Zhejiang University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Network Deployment and Capacity Configuration of Battery Swapping Stations for Heavy-Duty Electric Tractor Fleets in Field Work
detail.abstract: As farmers deal with the pressing challenges of today, the electrification of farm equipment has emerged as a promising solution, and electric tractors are taking a prominent position. The wider adoption of electric tractors faces the challenge of lacking infrastructure solutions for high-power electric tractors operating across vast, seasonal farmlands. The battery swapping stations equipped with standardized and “Lego-like” battery cells meet the high-volume charging demands and reduce downtime compared to conventional charging. To support the future infrastructure requirements of heavy-duty electric tractors, this paper addresses a critical gap in agricultural electrification by proposing a location selection and capacity configuration model for battery swapping stations and demonstrates its feasibility in a real-world scenario. By analyzing the spatiotemporal distribution pattern of the charging demand across multi-regional farmlands under a fully electrified scenario, the optimal deployment location for installing the battery swapping station is determined. Then, the capacity configuration model optimizes the number of charging bays and battery cells to minimize the annual investment cost. The case study validates the effectiveness of the deployment location selection and capacity configuration models.

title: Navigating Csr–Financial Performance Trade-Offs: A Paradoxical Perspective of Gender Diversity in Upper Echelons and the Role of Institutional Environment
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Norwegian University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Navigating Csr–Financial Performance Trade-Offs: A Paradoxical Perspective of Gender Diversity in Upper Echelons and the Role of Institutional Environment
detail.abstract: While the performance benefits of gender diversity in upper echelons are widely acknowledged, literature concerning how and under what institutional conditions such diversity enables the firm’s ability to simultaneously pursue financial and socio-environmental objectives is scarce. We propose a paradoxical perspective to examine the relationship between gender diversity in upper echelons and firm CSR and financial performance, and, adopting an institutional lens, further propose that this relationship is moderated by a country's cultural tightness and legal system. Using a sample of 4,129 firms across 25 countries from 2002 to 2021, we find that board and TMT gender diversity positively influences firm CSR and financial performance. Moreover, our findings show that cultural tightness and civil law system exert a positive moderating effect in this relationship, highlighting the contingent nature of gender diversity’s effects on firm outcomes.

title: Mapping the Intellectual Structure of School Culture and Leadership Research (2010–2025): A Bibliometric Analysis
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Ordu Üniversitesi

detail.title: Mapping the Intellectual Structure of School Culture and Leadership Research (2010–2025): A Bibliometric Analysis
detail.abstract: Leadership and culture stand out as two fundamental concepts that cannot be considered separately in the functioning of educational institutions. Considering leadership and school culture together is crucial for understanding how leadership shapes cultural structures and the role of culture in school effectiveness. To this end, this research, conducted to contribute to the literature gap in these areas, aims to examine scientific publications on school culture and leadership systematically. The study aims to analyze how these concepts are related, identify research trends that may guide the academic field, and identify potential research opportunities. Structured using a bibliometric analysis model, a quantitative research method, this study examined 2088 articles published in the Web of Science database between 2010 and 2025. VOSviewer software was utilized in the analysis process. The findings revealed a general upward trend in the number of publications over the years, but a significant decrease occurred in 2024. It was observed that the majority of the articles examined were published in leading, high-impact journals in the field. Analyses of keywords and abstracts revealed that "leadership" and "development" were among the most frequently used and salient terms. The study concludes with a discussion of the study's limitations and several recommendations for future research.

title: Measuring the Dark Side of Inspiration: Developing a Scale for Pseudo-Transformational Leadership
affiliations: Regis University and Regis University

detail.title: Measuring the Dark Side of Inspiration: Developing a Scale for Pseudo-Transformational Leadership
detail.abstract: This study addresses the need for a validated measure of pseudo-transformational leadership, a destructive leadership style often masked by superficial motives. Through exploratory and confirmatory analysis across two samples (n=515 and n=360), a six-item scale was developed capturing two key dimensions: Vison overreach (overextension of aspirational goals without realistic support) and Weaponized Mission (use of mission to manipulate and exploit employees). The resulting model demonstrates reliability and validity, accounting for over 81% of the variance. These findings provide a starting point for practitioners to identify unhealthy work environments with a tool to identify and assess the misuse of mission and vision within organizations. For researchers, this work provides an empirical measure for differentiating authentic and pseudo-transformational leadership and opens the door for future studies exploring the organizational consequences of these practices.

title: Joy at Work: A Strategic Neural and Organizational Imperative
affiliations: Shenandoah University

detail.title: Joy at Work: A Strategic Neural and Organizational Imperative
detail.abstract: Joy is often misconstrued as a soft perk, relegated to workplace morale boosters or token gestures, such as ping pong tables and pizza parties. However, neuroscience and organizational research tell a different story. Joy, rooted in neurochemical balance, psychological safety, and meaning making, is a foundational condition for cognitive function,engagement, and equity. My paper integrates interdisciplinary insights from neurology, trauma-informed leadership, neurodiversity, and organizational psychology to argue that cultivating joy at work is not only ethical and humane but also essential for sustained performance, innovation, and inclusion.Drawing from course content, scholarly literature, and deeply personal reflection, I propose that joy is not a byproduct but a prerequisite for thriving workplaces.

title: Optimization of Carriage Parking Based on Simulation of Passenger Dynamics in the Dynamic Autonomous Non-Stop Rail Transit System
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Chang’an University

detail.title: Optimization of Carriage Parking Based on Simulation of Passenger Dynamics in the Dynamic Autonomous Non-Stop Rail Transit System
detail.abstract: This study investigates the carriage parking problem in the dynamic autonomous non-stop rail transit (DANRT) system, with a particular focus on the movement behaviors of passengers. A cell transmission model (CTM) is formulated to depict the movement behaviors of passengers in the DANRT system and the interactions between passengers. The parameters in the CTM are calibrated by using a set of video recordings and reproducing the arching phenomenon of passengers. To optimize carriage parking schemes, a swarm intelligence-based heuristic algorithm is proposed, where the CTM is embedded into the evaluation process to dynamically assess passenger moving efficiency during each iteration. We conduct a set of numerical experiments to evaluate the effect of algorithm parameters on algorithm performance and the influence of passenger behaviors on passenger waiting times. The results demonstrate that the algorithm can further optimize a theoretically optimal solution obtained when the movement behaviors and interactions of passengers are not considered. Additionally, overall system efficiency is maximized when the frequency of carriage re-selection behavior of passengers is maintained at a moderate level. Moreover, it is essential to deliberately designate carriages for passengers so as to improve the travel efficiency of passengers in the DANRT system.

title: Managerial Loneliness in the Workplace: Conceptualization, Scale Development, and Structural Modeling Using Ism
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Managerial Loneliness in the Workplace: Conceptualization, Scale Development, and Structural Modeling Using Ism
detail.abstract: Managerial loneliness, which differs fundamentally from general workplace loneliness, remains conceptually underdeveloped and lacks a validated measurement instrument. This study aims to fill this gap by conceptualizing the dimensions of managerial loneliness, developing and validating a dedicated scale, and modeling the structural relationships among its core components. Following a sequential exploratory mixed-methods approach, the study began with 24 semi-structured interviews analyzed using Glaser’s grounded theory to extract foundational themes. These insights informed the initial design of a measurement instrument, which was subsequently refined using Fuzzy Delphi, statistically validated via Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA), and structurally analyzed through Fuzzy DEMATEL and Interpretive Structural Modeling (ISM). The findings reveal two overarching dimensions—deficiencies in work-related and non-work-related relationships—encompassing nine subdimensions and thirty validated indicators. Structural modeling indicates that perceived deficits in legitimacy, professional support, and formal recognition act as foundational causal factors, exacerbating other relational deficiencies. This study contributes both theoretically and practically by clarifying the structure of managerial loneliness, providing a reliable tool for its assessment, and illuminating the internal mechanisms that intensify managerial loneliness in organizational contexts.

title: A Novel Energy Efficiency Enhancement Strategy Based on Parameter Optimization for Air-Conditioning System in Metro Station
affiliations: Tianjin University, Tianjin University, Tianjin University, Tianjin University, Tianjin University, Tianjin University, Tianjin University, Tianjin University and University College London

detail.title: A Novel Energy Efficiency Enhancement Strategy Based on Parameter Optimization for Air-Conditioning System in Metro Station
detail.abstract: A comprehensive mathematical model of a metro station air-conditioning system is developed by coupling semi-empirical component models of the chiller, pump, cooling tower, water system, and terminal cooling coil. The model incorporates thermodynamic principles and control strategies to simulate and optimize system performance under varying loads and chilled water supply temperatures. Validation against field data from a typical metro station shows good agreement, with a average COP error of 6.70% and EER error of 8.28%. Simulation results reveal that system efficiency improves with increased load and optimized chilled water supply temperature. A cooperative optimization method combining Bayesian optimization and simulated annealing is proposed to optimize the chilled water supply temperature, significantly enhancing system energy efficiency—with monthly average energy efficiencies of the chiller and refrigeration plant room improved by 7.81% and 5.44%, respectively—while also reducing operating costs (AEPC down 4.5%, LCC reduced by 101,000 CNY, and PP shortened by 0.9 years) and cutting CO2 emissions by 130.2 tons. The proposed model and strategy provide a practical foundation for improving the energy efficiency and sustainability of metro air conditioning systems.

title: How Do Multidimensional Proximity Optimize the Robustness of Collaborative Innovation Networks: A Case Study of China's Smart Grid Industry
affiliations: Anhui Normal University

detail.title: How Do Multidimensional Proximity Optimize the Robustness of Collaborative Innovation Networks: A Case Study of China's Smart Grid Industry
detail.abstract: The robustness optimization of collaborative innovation network is an important part of industrial innovation strategy, which has a profound impact on the improvement of industrial core competitiveness and sustainable development. Based on China's smart grid industry cooperation patents from 2016 to 2021, this paper uses social network analysis method to build collaborative innovation network, describes the connotation of network robustness optimization, and puts forward the idea of network robustness optimization. Simulation analysis is used to optimize the network robustness from the perspective of network subject heterogeneity. Then, based on the heterogeneity of network subjects, the network robustness is optimized and simulated from the perspective of multidimensional proximity. It is found that the network robustness optimization based on subject heterogeneity is better than the existing network on the whole, and the connection between large and small nodes makes the network robustness optimal. The network robustness optimization based on subject heterogeneity and multidimensional proximity is better than the existing network and the optimized network of large-small node connections. Among them, the optimized network of large-small node connections that are geographically and organizationally not close to each other has the best robustness in face of random or deliberate failure of nodes and edge. Based on this, this paper proposes countermeasures and suggestions for network robustness optimization from the aspects of promoting cooperation among strong-weak, cross-regional and different organization types of innovation subjects.

title: An Efficient Deep Template Matching and In-Plane Pose Estimation Method Via Template-Aware Dynamic Convolution
affiliations: Chengdu University of Information Technology, Chengdu University of Information Technology, Chengdu University of Information Technology, Chengdu University of Information Technology, Ningbo University and Chengdu University of Information Technology

detail.title: An Efficient Deep Template Matching and In-Plane Pose Estimation Method Via Template-Aware Dynamic Convolution
detail.abstract: In industrial inspection and component alignment tasks, template matching requires efficient estimation of a target's position and geometric state (rotation and scaling) under complex backgrounds to support precise downstream operations. Traditional methods rely on exhaustive enumeration of angles and scales, leading to low efficiency under compound transformations. Meanwhile, most deep learning-based approaches only estimate similarity scores without explicitly modeling geometric pose, making them inadequate for real-world deployment. To overcome these limitations, we propose a lightweight end-to-end framework that reformulates the task as joint localization and geometric regression. A Template-Aware Dynamic Convolution Module (TDCM) dynamically injects template features at inference to guide generalizable matching. The compact network integrates depthwise separable convolutions and pixel shuffle for efficient matching. To enable annotation-free training, we introduce a rotation-shear-based augmentation strategy with structure-aware pseudo labels. A lightweight refinement module further improves angle and scale precision via local optimization. Experiments show our 3.07M model achieves high precision and ∼14ms inference under compound transformations. It also demonstrates strong robustness in small-template and multi-object scenarios, making it highly suitable for deployment in real-time industrial applications. The code is available at: https://github.com/ZhouJ6610/PoseMatch-TDCM/tree/main

title: Weakly Supervision of Bolt Sorting Guided by Template-Based Border Measurement
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Xiamen University of Technology

detail.title: Weakly Supervision of Bolt Sorting Guided by Template-Based Border Measurement
detail.abstract: The trade in bundles of industrial equipment has increased the demand for bolt inspection during reassembly. Manual inspection carries the risk of errors, and conventional vision-based systems struggle to sort bolts effectively. The primary obstacles include the limited availability of annotated bolt data, frequent updates to bolt models, and the similarities in appearance and dimensions between different models. We propose a weakly supervised bolt sorting framework using size-guided keypoint template matching. This monocular camera-based solution integrates supervision with template matching and dimensional image measurement to accommodate model variations driven by task requirements, supporting rapid system iteration. We developed a bolt dataset that contains hundreds of visually similar types. Experiments demonstrate that our method achieves superior measurement accuracy with fewer samples, showing competitiveperformance in this dataset.

title: Anomaly Detection for Antenna-Based Defect Detection in Additive Manufacturing: A Grounded, Instructible, and Aligned Learning Framework
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University and University of Maryland

detail.title: Anomaly Detection for Antenna-Based Defect Detection in Additive Manufacturing: A Grounded, Instructible, and Aligned Learning Framework
detail.abstract: Additive manufacturing enables the layer-by-layer fabrication of complex and customizable structures but remains prone to internal defects that are difficult to detect during fabrication. This work presents an anomaly detection framework for real-time defect monitoring using a custom-designed wireless antenna sensor. The sensor consists of an aluminum split-ring resonator patterned with gold conductive ink and mounted on a ceramic substrate. It passively responds to structural and thermal changes during the manufacturing process by producing frequency-domain scattering parameter signals. To process these high-dimensional signals without requiring defect labeled data, we develop a zero-bias deep neural network trained exclusively on normal-class samples. The model constructs a class-structured latent space using cosine similarity to learned templates and applies Mahalanobis distance to define statistical decision boundaries. Anomalies are identified when inputs deviate significantly from the expected distribution of normal data. The framework is designed around three deployment-oriented principles. Grounding ensures that model outputs can be interpreted in terms of meaningful spectral features. Instructibility allows users to tune detection sensitivity through threshold control without retraining. Alignment guarantees that the internal decision logic is consistent with process tolerances and quality objectives in manufacturing. The system is evaluated using experimental data collected from the antenna sensor under controlled thermal variation. Results demonstrate that the proposed method accurately detects anomalous signal patterns without using defect supervision, while maintaining interpretability and user control. This approach offers a transparent, adaptive, and data-efficient solution for in situ defect monitoring in additive manufacturing environments.

title: Assessing Ridership Impacts of Fare-Free Transit Policies Through Agency- and Neighborhood-Level Models
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Independent

detail.title: Assessing Ridership Impacts of Fare-Free Transit Policies Through Agency- and Neighborhood-Level Models
detail.abstract: This study assesses the long-term effects of fare-free transit (FFT) policies on ridership, at both the agency and neighborhood levels. Using a Fixed Effects model with Instrumental Variables on data from 125 U.S. transit agencies (2011–2023), we found that partial-route and full FFT policies increased agency-level ridership by approximately 17% and 45%, respectively. Then, employing and a Spatial Durbin model with Fixed Effects on bus data from Boston, MA, USA (2021–2023), we found that neighborhoods served by FFT routes saw 26% more boardings than those served by non-FFT routes. The impact of FFT also varied by time of day, with smaller effects observed during peak hours, evenings, and weekends. By distinguishing between types of FFT policies (i.e., full, partial-population, or partial-route) and their spatial and temporal effects, this study offers actionable insights for transit agencies. These insights are particularly relevant for agencies aiming to maximize ridership growth while balancing factors, such as service coverage, serving population, and budget constraints.

title: M3sa: Exploring Datacenter Performance and Climate-Impact with Multi- and Meta-Model Simulation and Analysis
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: M3sa: Exploring Datacenter Performance and Climate-Impact with Multi- and Meta-Model Simulation and Analysis
detail.abstract: Datacenters are vital for the digital society but represent a considerable fraction of global energy consumption. To improve their sustainability and performance when demand is foreseen to increase, we envision simulators will become primary decision-making tools. However, unlike other fields focusing on key societal infrastructure such as waterworks and mass transit, datacenter simulators cannot yet combine multiple, independent models into their operation. Addressing this challenge, in this work we propose M3SA, a datacenter simulation and analysis framework that uses discrete-event simulation to predict, per model and then combined into a meta-model, the impact on climate and performance of various realistic datacenter conditions. We design an architecture for simulating multiple concurrent models, a technique to integrate the results of multiple models into a meta-model, and a procedure to evaluate the accuracy of the meta-model. Through experiments with a prototype, we show that (i) M3SA can be used to reproduce peer-reviewed experiments, and enhance their output with more diverse metrics and more detailed analysis; (ii) M3SA can be configured with a variety of realistic parameters, such as diverse workload traces (using Grid Workloads Archive data in our experiments), and energy production data such as carbon intensity over time and location (gCO2/kWh data across all EU regions, from ENTSO-E); (iii) M3SA enables various types of what-if and how-to analysis, such as how to configure CO2-aware migration over yearly energy-production patterns. M3SA has been integrated into the open-source software simulator OpenDC and is available on https://github.com/atlarge-research/opendc-m3sa.

title: Multi-State Risk Performance Analysis Framework for Marine Traffic Systems Via Rf-Gat Integration: Evidence from Liquefied Gas Carrier Deficiencies Networks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Shanghai Maritime University (SMU), Guangdong Ocean University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Multi-State Risk Performance Analysis Framework for Marine Traffic Systems Via Rf-Gat Integration: Evidence from Liquefied Gas Carrier Deficiencies Networks

keywords.keywords: risk performancemulti-state systemmarine traffic systemcomplex networkliquefied gas carriersrandom forestgraph attention network

detail.abstract: The marine traffic system (MTS) is a complex and uncertain network topology system, and diagnosing its operational status is crucial for multi-state systems safety (MSS). To analyze the risk performance of multi-state systems under the mapping of ship combination features, this study proposes a system multi-state analysis framework integrating Random Forest (RF) and Graph Attention Network (GAT) models. First, based on the complex network characteristics of multi-state system components, the Euclidean distance is used to construct a dual-layer network of the MTS reflecting ship feature relationships. Second, the RF algorithm is introduced to build a ship feature importance analysis model, and GAT is applied to analyze the risk performance of MSS under the path of ship component networks. Finally, the proposed method is verified by simulation using the gas carrier safety inspection data from the Tokyo Memorandum(T-MOU). The data-driven results show that the state of the MTS from system components has significant correlations with external conditions such as ship age, gross tonnage, flag state, and classification society, presenting behavioral symptoms dominated by operation and maintenance state, with alternating influences of inherent and emergency status. The proposed risk performance analysis framework provides a novel perspective for describing multi-state risk of MTS, helping to analyze how changes in one subsystem propagate through the network and affect other subsystems through shared feature patterns and path dependence.

title: Unified System Intelligence: Learning Energy Strategies for Optimizing Operations, Maintenance, and Market Outcomes
affiliations: Government of the United States of America - Idaho National Laboratory and Government of the United States of America - Idaho National Laboratory

detail.title: Unified System Intelligence: Learning Energy Strategies for Optimizing Operations, Maintenance, and Market Outcomes
detail.abstract: In view of a multitude of efforts to realize technologically- and economically-viable, and long-term sustainable energy technologies and solutions, we develop a Reinforcement Learning (RL) approach to intelligent energy market bidding and broader plant operations and maintenance (O&M). Our approach is cognizant of current and future performance, maintenance, and economic aspects of the supervised system and its operational environment. Regardless of their energy generation modality (e.g., fossil, nuclear), the relatively-centralized systems that will complement distributed renewable energy in contemporary power grids will not only be subject to the complexity and typical operational, maintenance, and economic nuances of any complex production facility, but also be based on comparatively new technologies that yet need to prove competitive in increasingly tighter markets. The manner any production facility is run can have a profound effect on its operational and maintenance costs, whereas the multi-party bidding and market dynamics existing in contemporary energy markets largely dictate the operational envelopes and accrued costs for the entire facility. Our methodology establishes a long-horizon-aware intelligent feedback loop that bids strategically in day-ahead energy markets and supervises other operations and maintenance aspects (e.g., maintenance action selection and scheduling, slowdown or downtime considerations) in way that maximizes plant profitability by increasing revenues while controlling and distributing maintenance costs. The foundations of our approach are based not only on RL techniques to periodically (re-)construct stochastic, strongly-coupled bidding and plant supervision policies with receding reasoning horizons, but also on operationally-leaning learning and inference RL workflows. In addition to establishing the interfaces and mechanics of our RL agent, we prototype key aspects of the underlying techno-economic environment and relevant algorithmic and numerical tools and approximations that enable the sought-after reasoning. In contrast to isolated bidding algorithms operating under the premise of statistically- or offline-computed marginal costs disconnected from actual, day-to-day operations in the particular operational environment, our techniques learn to address the coupled problem of bidding and plant supervision holistically, within any particular operational environment defined by the local energy grid and market, as well as in view of their probabilistic behavior and future evolution.

title: Improving Real-World Execution of Optimized Trading Schedules for Large-Scale Battery Storage Systems Through Data-Driven Component Parametrization
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, RWTH Aachen University and RWTH Aachen University

detail.title: Improving Real-World Execution of Optimized Trading Schedules for Large-Scale Battery Storage Systems Through Data-Driven Component Parametrization
detail.abstract: Large-scale battery storage systems (BESS) play a key role in ancillary services and are set to contribute significantly to short-term energy trading. However, linear BESS optimization models for energy trading are often based on simplified assumptions, such as fixed component efficiencies. These simplifications fail to capture crucial operational constraints and result in discrepancies between scheduled and actual state of charge (SOC), leading to unfulfilled power delivery and financial penalties. This study addresses this gap by using field data from a real BESS to parametrize linear load-dependent efficiency models for inverters and transformers. Furthermore, the models are validated in the field by assessing their accuracy in calculating power delivery. This includes accounting for component efficiencies and SOC dynamics and comparing the results to a reference test. The data-driven parametrization presented in this study achieved a reduction of 78.2% in unfulfilled energy delivery and a 71.7% reduction in balancing energy costs caused by deviations compared to the reference test. It also significantly decreased the BESS round-trip efficiency deviation between modeled and measured values, with a 4.2 percentage point improvement over the reference test. The linear inverter model achieved a deviation from the actual measured round-trip efficiency of only 0.55 percentage points. These findings highlight the importance of accurate efficiency modeling in minimizing SOC deviations and fulfilling planned schedules in energy trading applications. Finally, this work proposes a methodology that is broadly applicable not only for energy trading with BESS, but also for ancillary services and multi-use operation.

title: A Hierarchical Mapping Architecture for Agent-Based Emotional Persuasion: Integrating Emotional Preference Membership with Cumulative Prospect Theory
affiliations: Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Hierarchical Mapping Architecture for Agent-Based Emotional Persuasion: Integrating Emotional Preference Membership with Cumulative Prospect Theory
detail.abstract: In modern industrial environments, automated negotiation is a cornerstone of supply-chain optimization and e-procurement, yet most agent-based architectures inadequately model the emotional dynamics that drive humanoid negotiation interaction. This paper presents a novel software architecture for agent-based emotional persuasion in bilateral negotiations. Each agent is endowed with an OCEAN personality profile, and its round-by-round emotional state is generated via a hierarchical mapping from personality traits through the Pleasure-Arousal-Dominance (PAD) state to discrete emotion categories. To capture the inherent uncertainty between emotion and persuasive behavior, an emotional preference membership function is introduced to quantify how an agent’s emotional state probabilistically influences its choice of persuasive strategy. The Cumulative Prospect Theory then transforms these preferences into concrete offers and counter-offers. The proposed architecture is validated with extensive simulation experiments in industrial purchasing scenarios. Compared to emotion-blind baselines, the constructed emotionally intelligent agents achieve significantly higher negotiation success rates, require fewer rounds to reach agreement, and deliver greater joint utility—while maintaining equitable utility distribution between parties. Comparative analyses against state-of-the-art models further demonstrate the proposed architecture’s ability to accelerate consensus and improve negotiated outcomes. This work lays a robust foundation for deploying emotionally aware negotiation agents in real-world industrial systems.

title: Transient Modeling of Pulsed Sieve Tray Extraction Columns: Parameter Estimation, Uncertainty Analysis, and Operation Optimization
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and RWTH Aachen University

detail.title: Transient Modeling of Pulsed Sieve Tray Extraction Columns: Parameter Estimation, Uncertainty Analysis, and Operation Optimization
detail.abstract: Despite considerable modeling efforts in extraction research, transient models of extraction columns are rarely used in industrial practice. The most prominent objection concerns the reliability and extrapolation capabilities of model parameters under varying operating conditions. To address these concerns, we evaluated the uncertainty propagation from estimated parameters onto the outputs of our column model (introduced in previous work) and assessed parameter identifiability through an ill-conditioning analysis. Additionally, we examined parameter extrapolation capabilities by conducting parameter estimation (PE) based on fluid dynamic experiments while validating the model outputs with mass transfer experiments. The PE was performed using the maximum likelihood approach with our own experiments conducted in a DN50 pulsed sieve tray extraction column. We selected the parameters d_stab,d_100, and the swarm exponent n for PE as they immanently impact the drop diameter d and hold-up α_y, i.e., properties measurable online in our experimental setup. Incorporating the estimated parameters, the column model demonstrated good agreement (e_rel<10 %) on key fluid dynamic properties such as d, α_y, and both stationary and transient concentration profiles in the mass transfer experiments. As a prospective operation optimization task, we utilized our column model to determine the minimal solvent demand to extract 99% of the product for two column experiments. The final uncertainty analysis demonstrated robustness of the parameter estimates by yielding coefficients of variation < 4% for d and α_y , while achieving even smaller values in the concentration profiles and for the minimal solvent demand.

title: Capturing and Sharing Knowledge with Extended Reality and Artificial Intelligence: A Human-Centered Approach for Industrial Training
affiliations: Polytechnic University of Milan, Polytechnic University of Milan, Istituto Nazionale di Astrofisica (INAF) - Milano and Polytechnic University of Milan

detail.title: Capturing and Sharing Knowledge with Extended Reality and Artificial Intelligence: A Human-Centered Approach for Industrial Training
detail.abstract: This paper proposes a methodology grounded on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and eXtended Reality (XR) to address the challenge companies face in keeping workforce skills aligned with fast-paced technological change and high employee turnover. While XR technologies offer promising potential in industrial training, they are still often limited to a few pilot applications. A novel AI-based XR training system that enables real-time knowledge capture from expert users is presented. This system allows trainers to author training procedures directly in an XR scenario, making the development of XR training systems as intuitive as instructing a novice worker. An AI-powered Digital Assistant (AIDA) supports this process by collecting, organizing, and delivering context-specific information to users during task execution, while full-body motion capture tracks postures and interactions. The training experience is made directly accessible to inexperienced workers through an XR-based training system supported by AIDA. The system was tested in two case studies with participants of varying expertise levels. Following the Kirkpatrick model of training evaluation, the solution was assessed considering the Reaction and Learning levels. Results show high usability, low cognitive load, and positive user engagement. The second case study also demonstrated strong learning outcomes. Overall, the system proves to be a flexible and effective approach to training, leveraging XR and AI to bridge skill gaps and update the approach to training in industrial settings.

title: Digital Entrepreneurship Ecosystem in Emerging Tourism Economies: Evidence from Sri Lanka
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Uva Wellassa University

detail.title: Digital Entrepreneurship Ecosystem in Emerging Tourism Economies: Evidence from Sri Lanka
detail.abstract: The research focuses on the structure and effects of the Digital Entrepreneurship Ecosystem (DEE) in the context of Sri Lankan tourism. Although there is escalating literature on digital entrepreneurship, there is limited empirical analysis on the operational aspects of DEE in developing, service-oriented regions. The study uses a cross-sectional quantitative survey of 380 tourism entrepreneurs from five regions and applies the DEE framework through its operational components: digital infrastructure, platforms, skills, institutional support, sociocultural networks, and digital finance. Regression analysis suggests that entrepreneurship performance is driven by digital platforms, infrastructure, and skills. Both institutional support and financial mechanisms display positive, albeit weaker, impacts. Moderation analysis also shows that the relationships are impacted by firm size, entrepreneurial experience, and technological readiness. Collectively, these results support the validity of the DEE model in resource-constrained settings and expose underlined structural inequities and systemic gaps within the ecosystem.The research expands the DEE framework into the context of the service industry within emerging economies and offers practical guidance for policymakers. Key suggestions are addressing equity gaps in infrastructure, advancing strategic digital capacity-building initiatives, and improving coherence among overarching policies. The paper adds to the body of academic literature on the theory and practice of digital entrepreneurship in tourism-driven economies.

title: Key-Augmented Neural Triggers for Knowledge Sharing
affiliations: University of Zurich, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Zurich and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Key-Augmented Neural Triggers for Knowledge Sharing
detail.abstract: Repository-level code comprehension and knowledge sharing remain core challenges in software engineering. Large language models (LLMs) have shown promise by generating explanations of program structure and logic. However, these approaches still face limitations: First, relevant knowledge is distributed across multiple files within a repository, aka semantic fragmentation. Second, retrieval inefficiency and attention saturation degrade performance in RAG pipelines, where long, unaligned contexts overwhelm attention. Third, repository specific training data is scarce and often outdated. Finally, proprietary LLMs hinder industrial adoption due to privacy and deployment constraints. To address these issues, we propose Key-Augmented Neural Triggers (KANT), a novel approach that embeds knowledge anchors into both training and inference. Unlike prior methods, KANT enables internal access to repository specific knowledge, reducing fragmentation and grounding inference in localized context. Moreover, we synthesize specialized data directly from code. At inference, knowledge anchors replace verbose context, reducing token overhead and latency while supporting efficient, on premise deployment.We evaluate KANT via: a qualitative human evaluation of the synthesized dataset’s intent coverage and quality across five dimensions; compare against SOTA baselines across five qualitative dimensions and inference speed; and replication across different LLMs to assess generalizability. Results show that the synthetic training data aligned with information-seeking needs. KANT achieved over 60% preference from human annotators and a LocalStack expert (preferring 79% of cases). Also, KANT reduced inference latency by up to 85% across all models. Overall, it is well-suited for scalable, low-latency, on-premise deployments, providing a strong foundation for code comprehension.

title: Multi-Task Deep Learning for Spatiotemporal Reconstruction of Groundwater Dynamics in the North China Plain
affiliations: Harbin Institute of Technology, Southern University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Southern University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Multi-Task Deep Learning for Spatiotemporal Reconstruction of Groundwater Dynamics in the North China Plain
detail.abstract: Accurate prediction of groundwater spatiotemporal dynamics is critical for sustainable groundwater resource management. This study presents a novel ​Multi-Task Learning Groundwater Model (MTLGW)​​, which integrates time-series decomposition (STL) with LSTM/GRU neural networks to reconstruct regional-scale groundwater levels across the North China Plain (NCP), including data-scarce regions. Using 559 monitoring wells (2005–2018) and GLDAS-CLSM datasets, MTLGW achieves robust performance, with an ​average R² of 0.63​ (median: 0.64) across the NCP. The model demonstrates strong transferability, achieving a test R² of 0.48 in regions with limited observations. Key predictors such as 40-month lagged autocorrelation and Continuous Wavelet Transform coefficients (scale = 20) significantly enhance model accuracy. Spatial performance varies with higher accuracy in agricultural zones (R² = 0.50) compared to urban areas (R² = 0.47), likely due to complex anthropogenic influences. MTLGW also reconstructs shallow groundwater storage changes in the NCP comparing them to GLDAS estimates.  Results show that the South-to-North Water (SNWT) markedly alleviated groundwater storage depletion across the NCP. For example, Beijing experienced recovery (+48 mm/year), while the decline in Henan slowed (−30 mm/year). These findings highlight GLDAS’s underestimation of human interventions such as SNWT and underscore MTLGW’s strength in capturing anthropogenic impacts. By integrating multi-task learning with time-series decomposition, MTLGW advances regional-scale groundwater modeling and offers a scalable framework for data-limited basins worldwide, helping bridge the gaps between AI-based predictions and sustainable groundwater management.

title: Who Cares About Ethical Practices at Workplace! Unethical Leader Behavior and Employee Embeddedness
affiliations: Indian Institute of Management Udaipur

detail.title: Who Cares About Ethical Practices at Workplace! Unethical Leader Behavior and Employee Embeddedness
detail.abstract: Establishing and institutionalizing an unethical culture within organizations are complex processes involving multiple factors. This study aims to provide a theoretical rationale that sheds light on these processes from the perspectives of leaders and employees, using two distinct theories: the attraction-selection-attrition model and the theory of embeddedness. Drawing on the attraction-selection-attrition model, it seeks to examine the role of leaders who leverage their position of authority to attract and retain employees who share their values, including those that may be unethical.
